body:
the markers ini option is for making markers known (so strict markers can be used to fail on typos instead of just warning

the mark expressions do not have a ini variant and must be passed in addopts - its strongly recommended not to do that for lack of a reverse/reset of those options

ok, thank you for the explanation ! Does that mean there is no way to have default markers enabled when running the `pytest` command?

I could create a shell script that just calls `pytest -m "not slow"` but that does not seem right.

https://pypi.org/project/pytest-skip-slow/ is a example of a plugin implementing the pattern

its possible to override the default marker expression on the cli, but its confusing, thus its not recommended

ok thank you very much for your help.

Closing this issue.

Any reason why "`the mark expressions do not have a ini variant`"?

Btw, i'm gonna open a pull request to clarify the role of the `marker` property in pytest.ini

issue.title: Clarified `markers` ini property. Fix #11738

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
Clarified `markers` ini property. Fix #11738

- [x] Include documentation when adding new features.
- [ ] Include new tests or update existing tests when applicable.
- [X] Allow maintainers to push and squash when merging my commits. Please uncheck this if you prefer to squash the commits yourself.

If this change fixes an issue, please:

- [x] Add text like ``closes #XYZW`` to the PR description and/or commits (where ``XYZW`` is the issue number). See the [github docs](https://help.github.com/en/github/managing-your-work-on-github/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue#linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue-using-a-keyword) for more information.

Unless your change is trivial or a small documentation fix (e.g., a typo or reword of a small section) please:

- [ ] Create a new changelog file in the `changelog` folder, with a name like `<ISSUE NUMBER>.<TYPE>.rst`. See [changelog/README.rst](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/main/changelog/README.rst) for details.

  Write sentences in the **past or present tense**, examples:

  * *Improved verbose diff output with sequences.*
  * *Terminal summary statistics now use multiple colors.*

  Also make sure to end the sentence with a `.`.

- [ ] Add yourself to `AUTHORS` in alphabetical order.
-->

body:
There is no sane way to undo a default

So if a default is enforced, it's tricky and hard to comprehend the implications for cli usage

So far nobody proposed a good solution, it's unlikely we'll have a reasonable solution with the current configuration system in place

we could have a section `[pytest.defaults]`for "pytest.ini" and `[tool.pytest.defaults]` for "pyproject.ini".

In such section, we would find the same parameters than for the CLI. It would give something like

```toml
[tool.pytest.defaults]
failed-first = true
quiet = true
strict-markers = true
k = "test_pipelines not test_pipelines_prediction"
m = "not slow"
```
Personally I'm not willing to implement that on the currently existing already broken configuration system and I'm not exactly keen on maintaining a implementation either
Is the broken configuration system you refer to the one from python (pyproject.ini), or the one for pytest (with the multiple config file lookup)?
The pytest Config object and it's lifecycle/lifecycle in xdist

repository.name: multiview-stitcher
repository.description: A toolbox for registering / fusing / stitching large multi-view / multi-positioning image datasets in 2-3D.
